claim: Drinking excessive water can lead to hyponatremia

supporting.text: Hyponatremia occurs when sodium levels in the blood become dangerously low, and excessive water intake dilutes sodium concentration.

attacks.text: Hyponatremia occurs when sodium levels in the blood become dangerously low, and excessive water intake dilutes sodium concentration.
Hyponatremia is extremely rare in healthy individuals with normal kidney function, even with high water intake.
Kidney function declines with age or certain medical conditions, making hyponatremia a realistic risk for many people.
The body has effective regulatory mechanisms to excrete excess water before sodium dilution becomes dangerous.
These regulatory mechanisms can be overwhelmed during marathon running or psychogenic polydipsia.
Most cases of hyponatremia are caused by medical conditions or medications, not by water intake alone.
Water intoxication cases in military training and hazing incidents prove excessive water alone can cause hyponatremia.

supporting.text: Medical studies have shown that overhydration can overwhelm the kidneys' ability to excrete water, leading to electrolyte imbalance.

attacks.text: Medical studies have shown that overhydration can overwhelm the kidneys' ability to excrete water, leading to electrolyte imbalance.
The kidneys are highly efficient at excreting excess water under normal conditions, making hyponatremia rare in healthy individuals.
Even in healthy individuals, excessive water intake in a short period (e.g., water-drinking contests) can overwhelm renal capacity.
Most documented cases of hyponatremia involve underlying medical conditions or extreme circumstances, not typical overhydration.
Several case studies show hyponatremia occurring in otherwise healthy marathon runners due to excessive water consumption during races.

supporting.text: Athletes, particularly marathon runners, are at risk of hyponatremia due to excessive water consumption without adequate electrolyte replacement.

attacks.text: Athletes, particularly marathon runners, are at risk of hyponatremia due to excessive water consumption without adequate electrolyte replacement.
Most athletes are educated about hydration and electrolyte balance, reducing the risk of hyponatremia in this group.
Studies show that even educated athletes can overhydrate during events due to psychological factors and misinformation.
Hyponatremia is extremely rare and mostly occurs in extreme cases, not typical athletic scenarios.
Marathon medical tents report consistent cases of hyponatremia annually, indicating it is not as rare as claimed.

supporting.text: The National Kidney Foundation warns that drinking too much water in a short period can cause hyponatremia, which may lead to seizures or coma.

attacks.text: The National Kidney Foundation warns that drinking too much water in a short period can cause hyponatremia, which may lead to seizures or coma.
Hyponatremia is extremely rare in healthy individuals with normal kidney function, even with excessive water intake.
The National Kidney Foundation's warning specifically applies to vulnerable populations, such as endurance athletes or those with kidney disorders.
The human body has natural mechanisms, like urination, to prevent hyponatremia from normal water consumption.
These natural mechanisms can be overwhelmed by extreme water intake, such as in water-drinking contests.
The warning doesn't specify what constitutes 'too much water', making it potentially alarmist without quantitative context.
Medical guidelines define excessive water intake as more than 1 liter per hour for several hours.

supporting.text: Clinical guidelines recommend limiting water intake to avoid hyponatremia, especially in individuals with conditions affecting kidney function.

attacks.text: Clinical guidelines recommend limiting water intake to avoid hyponatremia, especially in individuals with conditions affecting kidney function.
Clinical guidelines are not universally applicable and may not account for individual variations in hydration needs.
Individual hydration needs can be assessed through medical evaluation, making generalized guidelines still useful as a baseline.
Hyponatremia is rare in healthy individuals, and excessive water intake is not a common issue for the general population.
Even in healthy individuals, extreme water consumption (e.g., during endurance sports) can still lead to hyponatremia.

supporting.text: Case reports document instances of fatal hyponatremia resulting from excessive water consumption during endurance events or water-drinking contests.

attacks.text: Case reports document instances of fatal hyponatremia resulting from excessive water consumption during endurance events or water-drinking contests.
Case reports are anecdotal and do not establish a causal link or generalizable risk for the general population.
Peer-reviewed studies have replicated findings of hyponatremia in controlled settings, supporting the case report observations.
Fatal hyponatremia is extremely rare and requires extreme water intake beyond typical excessive consumption.
Public health guidelines explicitly warn against excessive water intake during endurance events due to documented fatalities.
